msgSnippet: Does anyone know why the Protectable interface is needed in the design of JUnit?  Why couldn t they just put the call to runBare() directly in runProtected()?

Subject: Protectable - why?

Does anyone know why the Protectable interface is needed in the
design of JUnit?  Why couldn't they just put the call to runBare() 
directly in runProtected()?  I'm extending JUnit to permit deferred 
collection of assertion failures (so selected tests can continue if an 
assertion fails), and although the extension works I'm afraid I'm 
missing something.
subject: Protectable - why?
